title.narrative: Activity web page
Annual Output Results
Output Indicator

description.narrative: -The Ministry of Environment has a clear planning and programming agenda for sustainable environmental development including resource mobilization and updating environmental. -Technical needs of the Ministry of Environment are assessed and met.

comment.narrative: Enabling environment for sustainable environmental development remains limited

-Environmental protection is enforced through the issuance of the National Sustainable Development Strategy, formulation and issuance of a number of environmental laws and decrees and implementation of inspection visits. -The Ministry of Environment is strengthened through the improvement of some management systems.

Assessment of needs for capacity development in environmental sustainability: follow up on: the National sustainable Development Strategy project, Environmental Assessment of the Syrian Conflict & Priority Interventions project, Integrated Solid Waste Management, Waste Water Management, IS MoE Project Evaluation ToRs, LTA Environmental Policy Consultant. ‘Planning & programming for sustainable environmental development: Preparation of the MoE achievements, Participation to key meetings organized by the MoF, the MoFA and CDR to discuss the proposed WB Country Partnership Strategy, the EU Cooperation Priorities and the EIB, Correspondence with MoFA reference the planned 2nd meeting of the UNEA of UNEP. Resource mobilization: initiated and or followed up on several projects: EU/Environmental Reform, WB – Pollution Abatement project, EU/ Protection and Sustainable Development of Maritime Resources, Qaraoun Prevention Project, GEF/FAO/MoA-MoE project on “Sustainable Agricultural Livelihoods in Marginal Areas, Sustainable Tourism and Environmental Planning”, Participation to the second annual meeting of the Oil for Development. Draft and follow up on Decrees {(draft National Environmental Fund, draft Environmental Police, draft application decree of article 20 of law 444/2002 (economic incentives), draft decree to compensate the members of the National Council of Environment, draft decree to appoint 27 new staff at the MoE, Replacement of the draft decree to compensate MoE staff for the review of EIA reports by a draft ministerial decision} and decisions { decision to compensate MoE staff supporting internationally funded projects at the Ministry, decision on the review procedures of environmental audit studies}; Preparation of ToRs for consultant to assess MoE’s management of the Environmental Assessment system; Grant agreement with YMCA as Environmental Watchdogs; preparation of ToRs for LTA Legal Consultant:. Follow up on the preparation of a publication on UNDP-MoE

-Environmental protection is enhanced through the formulation, and/or adoption and/or implementation of key legislation, strategies, plans and projects. - the Ministry of Environment is strengthened through the improvement in the implementation of key policy instruments.

- Legislation: adoption of decree 167/2017 on economic incentives for environmental protection and follow up on the draft application decisions and citizen’s guide; follow up on the draft decrees organizing the national environmental fund, and compensating members of the national council for the environment, and the draft MoE decision to compensate staff supporting internationally funded projects (and reviewing EIAs); publication of the UN SG report on implementation of UN GA resolution 71-218 (oil slick)
- Strategies/plans: (1) NSDS: continued discussion on the way forward in relation to SDGs; elaboration of MoE’s integrated (environmental) vision for economic recovery; identification of MoE priorities at the governorate level; follow up on the environmental task force of the LCRP; (2) Land management: follow up on the proposal to prepare a masterplan for protecting mountains and managing natural sites, coastal zones and agricultural terrains; (3) ISWM: draft strategic vision; publication of the updated dumps masterplan; completion of the 2006 oil spill waste disposal; (4) Litani pollution prevention: follow up on roadmap implementation including mobilization of resources; (5) Oil & Gas: follow up with LPA on environmental considerations and contribution to the 3rd phase of the OfD program (2018-2020)
- MoE capacity building: publication of brochures on environmental safeguards and complaints; issuance of decree 1933/2017 appointing 12 technical staff and follow up on the recruitment of 25 environmental police members.

'-Environmental protection is enhanced through the formulation, and/or adoption and/or implementation of at least 5 key legislation, strategies, plans and projects; - The Ministry of Environment is strengthened through the improvement in the implementation of key policy instrument.

description.narrative: -Total funds donated to implement development projects - Number of projects supported and implemented through the donations -Number of Lebanese expatriate organizations and individuals signed up as ‘friends of Live Lebanon’ on the website or on the Facebook Group - Number of visits to the website -Number of workshops/events arranged worldwide under the name of or in association with Live Lebanon -number of volunteers involved with the promotion of LIVE LEBANON

comment.narrative: -No nationwide, formal, neutral and apolitical structure/channel for Lebanese Diaspora to be engaged in the support of local communities in the most deprived areas of the country -Remittances are mainly given as private donations to individuals -No online system to channel remittances collectively for developmental purposes
At least 3 community based projects are implemented At least 1 partnerships with private sector are developed At least two events are executed to ensure Live Lebanon project visibility

During the year of 2016, Live Lebanon has successfully implemented 3 projects in 3 different areas of Lebanon. The initiative has rehabilitated two schools, the Maroun Aboud Public School of Aley in Mount Lebanon and the public school of Qleyaa in the south. The number of beneficiaries is over 650 students attending classes from neighboring villages and different nationalities. The Maroun Aboud School suffered from inadequate infrastructure, inhibiting more enrollment, participation and proper education. Live Lebanon rehabilitated the toilets that were unsanitary for the use of the students and the roof covering all the school stopping the leakage that was effecting the health and safety of the students. In Qleyaa, the classrooms along with the playground were considered unsafe for the students and teachers residing in the school. In addition to the above stated activities, Live Lebanon is currently working on the Lab that is unequipped so that the students have a better practical education. These activities improved education level of both schools refining their environment and decreasing the risk of potential health effects.
Moreover, Live Lebanon has provided a generator to the municipality of Bhamdoun Al Mhata to keep the streetlights lit at night. The solution is set to decrease the number of casualties amongst 3,000 pedestrians and drivers due to power outages and power cuts that are common in the Lebanese society and especially in rural areas being the main cause of accidents or crimes.
Live Lebanon’s main focus for the year 2016, was finding ways and channels to expand the reach of Live Lebanon to implement projects that benefit more than one area and have a large scope of impact. Live Lebanon team participated in the Lebanese Diaspora Energy 2016 in Beirut as exhibitors, New York and in Sao Paulo. The initiative was exposed to Lebanese expatriates all over the world, spreading the word and goals it has always aimed to achieve. This has given Live Leba
At least 5 community based projects are implemented At least 1 partnerships with private sector are developed At least two events are executed to ensure Live Lebanon project visibility

During the year of 2017, Live Lebanon has successfully implemented the following projects / campaigns:
Ensa Joura: Fixing potholes in 92 areas in Lebanon The highlight of 2017 was “Ensa Joura”, a campaign that reached almost all Lebanese municipalities closing around 6000 potholes enhancing road safety and decreasing the number of accidents. This campaign engaged the civil society and the municipalities extending the campaign from 3 months to 8 months. Ensa Joura was launched in Partnership with MTV our media partner with 60 news reports and 2 TVCs that were aired during the whole implementation phase. The campaign won the best advertising strategy in the MENA for 2017.
HSBC: Drip Irrigation Network in Deir El Ahmar HSBC funded a drip irrigation network that was installed in Deir El Ahmar, Beit Mattar in the Bekaa Area; providing water to all the organic farms that didn’t have access to the water during the summer season decreasing agricultural produce that the farmers depend on for their income.
Medical Equipment for St. Therese Hospital Medical Equipment were provided to the Hospital of St. Therese in Hadath area enhancing medical services delivered by the hospital to Hadath and surrounding villages’ inhabitants.
Road Safety: Enhancing Road Safety in Schools In partnership with the National Council for Road Safety, Live Lebanon launched “Haki Ousal” campaign on the 10th of April 2017 at UNESCO. Live Lebanon Goodwill Ambassadors were awarded during the event by the head of ISF General Imad Osman. The campaign targets road safety in and surrounding the schools. The project is being implemented in 7 schools in Marjaayoun and 3 in Zrarieh and soon in 9 schools in Borj Al Barajneh. A road safety policy in addition to the assessment of the schools have been made for each school to initiate the training of the students, staff and bus drivers. Road safety clubs are being formed in each school to sustain the project and incorporate it in the school curriculum and

description.narrative: Strategy for solid waste management in Baalback adopted

comment.narrative: Absence of integrated solid waste management in Caza of Baalbek

- The Municipality of Baalbek is adequately equipped to manage solid waste: maintenance workshop is rehabilitated; the secondary collection system is upgraded through acquiring and refurbishing a number of trucks and other solid waste fleet; the bio-energy co-generators are procured for the successful operation of the biogas production plant; -The Kayal dumpsite is cleaned and temporarily closed as a first step towards its full rehabilitation.

'-The fleet of waste collection trucks was procured and handed over to the Baalbek municipality; - Baalbek maintenance workshop was rehabilitated and equipped; -The rehabilitation of the Kayal dumpsites could not be completed awaiting the construction of a proper sanitary landfill; -The bid to procure the co-generator was cancelled subsequent to the incident of setting the sorting/composting facilities on fire the night of 24/25 Sep 2016 by an unknown group; -The project was extended until 31 December 2016 awaiting the final decision on the remaining activities.

- Project work-plan and activities are revised in consultation with project partners - Supply the municipality of Baalbek with the needed co-generators for the proper operation of the biogas production facilities - Completion of Kayal dumpsite rehabilitation or alternative activity according to revised workplan

- The needed co-generators are already manufactured at the country of origin (Spain), and are being shipped to Lebanon; expected complete installation and commissioning by end of April 2018. - Consultation with the main partners is maintained in order to plan the remaining implementation of the project. A meeting will be scheduled at the beginning of 2018 to agree on the next steps.

'- Supply the municipality of Baalbek with the needed co-generators for the proper operation of the biogas production facilities; - Completion of Kayal dumpsite cleanup and closure (pending construcion and operation of sanitary landfill), or alternative activity depending on project board's decision; the achievement of this activity is strictly related to the implementation of other partners in Ballbeck facility (given that the integrated SW management plan is being implemented by various partners).

description.narrative: - Number of SMEs financed - Number of new jobs created in under-served regions - Number of SMEs received business support for financial inclusion - Number of individuals benefited from project interventions - Number of community development projects implemented

comment.narrative: - SMEs have limited access to credits in under-served regions of Lebanon - SMEs have limited access to business support in under-served regions of Lebanon - Local development initiatives scattered and implemented with limited impact
Increase job creation in under-served regions of Lebanon Support community development initiatives in under-served regions of Lebanon

In 2016, the ESFD completed the implementation of 102 small projects and 8 infrastructure projects in the sectors of potable water, waste water and solid waste. These projects contributed to the improvement of municipal services in small and vulnerable municipalities, and in communities hosting high concentration of Syrian refugees in North and Bekaa. In parallel, the ESFD launched several activities that help revive local economy including the implementation of hill lakes and irrigation canals, implementing accelerated vocational training, agricultural extension programs and supporting active cooperatives.
The ESFD financed a total of 500 projects (loans equaling LBP 14.5 billion) under its Risk Sharing Scheme (RSS) from January 2016 to October 2016, to increase the growth and prosperity for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the under-served regions of Lebanon. It is expected to close the year with an estimated 550 projects financed that are expected to create around 560 jobs. This will bring the total number of projects financed to an average of 3,500 with a value of LBP 93 billion. These projects are expected to have created around 3,300 jobs since the start of the RSS in 2011. In addition, 200 projects benefited from BDS services in 2016 bringing the total number of SMEs who benefited from business support to 1,500 since the start of the RSS in 2011.
Increase job creation in under-served regions of Lebanon Support community development initiatives in under-served regions of Lebanon

In 2017, a total of 462 projects (loans equalling LBP 12.5 billion) were financed to increase the growth and prosperity for small and medium enterprises in the under-served regions of Lebanon. These projects are expected to create 453 jobs. This brings the total loans disbursed under the Risk Sharing Scheme (RSS) to date to 4,027 loans with a total value of approximately LBP 107 billion. 20% of all loans were disbursed to female entrepreneurs, 41% of all loans were disbursed to the services sector, 38% to the trade sector, 12% to the industrial sector, and 9% to the agricultural sector. The average loan size is around LBP 26 million. A reported number of 3,767 jobs have been created.
Moreover, 154 projects (around 13 projects per month) directed through BDS officers were financed, accounting for almost 33% of total projects financed by partner banks.
Within its program to support municipal services in communities hosting Syrian refugees, the ESFD completed two large infrastructure projects in 2017 amounting to EUR 6.5 million and consisting of solid waste management facility in Bar Elias Bekaa and rehabilitation of potable water supply system in Wadi Khaled. In parallel, the ESFD launched the implementation of 6 agriculture infrastructure projects (hill lakes and irrigation canals) amounting to EUR 3.2 million and distributed in Mount Lebanon, Bekaa, North, Akkar and Nabatiyeh. In addition, and in line with its efforts to revive local economies, the ESFD committed a budget of EUR 1.5 million to support agricultural cooperatives in the sectors of beekeeping, fishery and olive production through provision of supplies, capacity building and extension programs.

title.narrative: Activity web page
Annual Output Results
Output Indicator

description.narrative: - Internship program established - Training provided to Parliamentary Administration employees - Support provided to Parliament to address reform issues with key stakeholders/participatory approach - Inter-parliamentary agreements reached - Accountability role of parliamentarians exercised and issues raised - Information disclosed - Tracking system for legislative process developed - Media Campaign to promote Human Rights Action Plan developed - Support provided to the Human Right Parliamentary Committee - National Human Rights Action Plan finalized and adopted

comment.narrative: Need to modernize the current organizational and administrative structure of the parliament, and to develop capacities of and provide support to the administration to address critical reform issues Need for further follow-up on Parliamentary Interrogations, and enhancing the understanding of government accountability to the Parliament Need to implement and follow-up on the National Human Rights Action Plan and mainstreaming Human Rights in Parliamentary work.

- At least 3 research studies (focusing on national priority areas) published and disseminated - Increasing the number of enrolled interns to accept at least 10 students - Organizing at least one public hearing session on regional development related to Syrian refugees - Mobilize resources to develop and realize the National Human Rights Implementation Plan
Achieved as planned

• Five public hearing sessions on regional development organized for the provinces of Akkar, Bekaa, North, South and Mount Lebanon with summary reports drafted. • One workshop to launch the SDGs toolkit with summary report drafted. • Lebanese Parliamentary Internship programme expanded and number of enrolled interns increased to accepting a minimum of 30 graduates. • A workshop on the importance of women’s participation in conflict resolution and negotiation and developing an electoral law, organized. • A workshop on the importance of adopting a gender quota in the electoral law or in the Lebanese Constitution, organized.

In 2017, and in the framework of providing technical support to the parliament towards inclusive participation in public policy and the legislative process, the project addressed key priority areas. It extensively worked on supporting the adoption of a women quota in the electoral parliamentary law in close coordination with the woman machinery. As such, the "Women in Politics" coalition was established and comprises 150 organizations working on awareness ways to introduce the quota. the project also worked closely with youth (specifically young girls) to address women related issues through SDGs as a conceptual framework for bridging research with policy making. Additionally, support was provided for the prevention of child marriage and the participation of women in related negotiation processes and formulation of laws, with a related strategy. As such, a draft law to raise the legal age of marriage to 18 was developed and submitted to Parliament. A debate was also held in Parliament with major political parties, and accordingly a summary report and recommendations developed. Awareness on the urgency of addressing the national waste management strategy and adopting an integrated solid waste management law was raised through an open parliamentary debated with related recommendations. The oversight function of the parliament was also exercised through one parliamentary oversight meeting (originally 2 planned for 2017), covering the Akkar area and bringing together all related stakeholders that discussed developmental challenges in this very remote and vulnerable area. Also, a workshop was held to address progress achieved on the National Human Rights Action Plan with all stakeholders including civil society. After graduating 6 interns in 2017, the Lebanese Parliamentary Internship Progarmme was transferred fully to the Parliamentary Administration after 6 years of implementation. Finally, one of the major results for 2017 was a workshop to engage parliamentarians in

title.narrative: Activity web page
Annual Output Results
Output Indicator

description.narrative: -Efficient and timely reporting by the Government of Lebanon to the Montreal Protocol sustained and compliance is met. -National awareness and capacity building are raised and legislative framework is updated.

comment.narrative: Efficient and timely reporting by the Government of Lebanon to the Montreal Protocol

- Progress report (CP) report for 2016 submitted to the MLF secretariat and ISP Phase 10 kicked-off. - Monitoring implementation of pilot project for ODS destruction project (implemented through UNIDO). - Follow up on the ODS licensing decree (enforcement of the new amended decree number 3277/2016); Imports quotas for 2018 issued. - Sun Safe Guide Activity Book for school students prepared. - On the 30th anniversary of the Montreal Protocol organized Poster design competition for Universities in Lebanon in coordination with the Climate Change Unit; the winner participated in the 29th MOP meeting; Lebanon received "the Award for Policy and Implementation Leadership" recognizing the extraordinary contributions for the success of the Montreal Protocol. - Ratification of the Kigali amendment is being followed up with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. - Project proposals were approved: implementation of enabling activities (EA) for the phase-down of HFCs (US$ 150,000); 3 K-CEP projects to support the government of Lebanon in corporation energy efficiency plans on the activities related to HPMPs and future HFCs phase-down (around US$ 500,000). - Lebanon representative was elected as "Chairman" of the Executive Committee of the Multilateral Fund to the Montreal Protocol for the year 2018.

description.narrative: - Pilot strategic plans developed in 2 regions in Lebanon - Territorial profiles used for elaboration on development plans - Training sessions on decentralization policies and strategic development - National Strategy for Beekeeping sector developed - Agreements and funding from DC European local authorities

comment.narrative: - Absence of a national and regional development strategy - Territorial Profiles developed for South, BSS, North and Bekaa - Efforts for Decentralization law endorsement are ongoing, implementation at the regional and local still on hold - Decentralized cooperation agreements with european local authorities (Spain, Belgium, Monaco and Italy) - LEDAs registered and ready to start operation - Open EC call for proposals include International organizations

The ART GOLD Lebanon project ensured the implementation of the 4 areas activities (South, Bekaa, North, and Beirut Souther Suburbs). In addition, the project is implementing a Decentralized Cooperation agreement funded by Monaco. As such, under this framework of “setting integrated plans and services for welfare and heath in eight municipalities”, in 2017, the preliminary planning exercises at the local level in Chiah, Haret Hreik, Bourj Hammoud, Byblos, Barr Elias, and Baalbeck were completed. Moreover, the capacity building training on Planning Tools was carried out, targeting the directors, nurses, social workers of the SDCs and PHCCs, and staff from the municipalities’ Development Office. Furthermore, a developer completed the upgrading of the Health Information System of the Ministry of Public Health. The main objective was to update the system through a Web Application. The project followed up on the activities of the 4 Local Economic Development Agencies to ensure their sustainability.

The ART GOLD Lebanon project ensured the implementation of the 2 areas activities (North, and Beirut Southern Suburbs). In addition, the project is implementing a Decentralized Cooperation agreement funded by Monaco. As such, under this framework of “setting integrated plans and services for welfare and heath in eight municipalities”, in 2017, the preliminary planning exercises at the local level in Chiah, Haret Hreik, Bourj Hammoud, Byblos, Barr Elias, and Baalbeck were completed. Moreover, the capacity building training on Planning Tools was carried out, targeting the directors, nurses, social workers of the SDCs and PHCCs, and staff from the municipalities’ Development Office.
The project also followed up on the activities of the Local Economic Development Agencies to ensure their sustainability.

comment.narrative: - Limited public and greed spaces within Tripoli city - Local and regional authorities don't have strategic plans to aid them manage development challenges more effectively - Limited job opportunities for youth with no specific skills - Weak cultural activities within Akkar region, and youth inclined to delinquent behavoirs - Limited number of small and medium enterprises services - Excess use of fertilizers by farmers - Absence of business opportunities in the poor regions of the North - GIS already exists in Tripoli but not used effectively for planning purposes
- Ensure that the Decentralized Cooperation is strengthened - Ensure that the capacity of the Local Economic Development in the North is enhanced

The ART GOLD North project is implementing a Decentralized Cooperation intervention contributing at empowering Mediterranean local authorities (both decentralized authorities and State local agencies) and private stakeholders in the multilevel decision-making processes aimed at achieving a better management of coastal cities. Under this framework, the project is finalizing the final component – historical texts - relevant the “Support the Management of touristic and cultural sites in the Urban Community El Fayhaa”. Moreover, the project is working closely with the Local Economic Development Agency in the North to enhance the capacity of staff as well as the board members and to ensure the sustainability of the Agency.
- Ensure that the Decentralized Cooperation is strengthened - Ensure that the capacity of the Local Economic Development in the North is enhanced

description.narrative: - Number of vulnerable youth and related families identified and involved in community development activities - Social Municipal offices set and operational - Number of social and economic studies and surveys produced - Development of relevant action plans - Number of students supported by the extra-curricular activities - Number of teachers trained on educational and extra-curricular activities - Evaluation of the 3 PHCCs based on relevant indicators (infrastructure, equipments, medical record use, disease management, outreach projects and public awareness etc.) - Local Economic Development office established and operational - Number of small enterprises supported - Number of new jobs created

comment.narrative: - Absence of a regional development strategy in BSS - Prevalence of increased number of vulnerable youths (particularly drugs and alcohol addicts) - Lack of educational technical assistance for students with special needs and with difficulties in learning foreign languages -Lack of extra-curricular activities -Absence of social worker’s support in the schools with lack of parents’ involvement in the educational program of their children. - 55% of the population has no public or private health insurance coverage - Existing dispensaries do not follow the generic Primary Health Care Services System and Approach - Absence of business opportunities in BSS
- Ensure that the Decentralized Cooperation is strengthened - Ensure that the capacity of the Local Economic Development in the BSS is enhanced

The project is implementing a Decentralized Cooperation intervention aiming at promoting the role of the Municipality as a local institution, to valorize, to orient and to link between different realities on the territory in collaboration with the governmental authorities. In parallel, representatives of Tuscany region conducted missions to strengthen the professional capacities of the PHCC personnel to ensure enhanced social and health services and build trust between the community and the PHCC. Moreover, the project is working closely with the Local Economic Development Agency in the BSS to enhance the capacity of staff as well as the board members and to ensure the sustainability of the Agency. During 2016, UNDP continues to providing a technical and financial support, which resulted in the enhancing and functioning of the core units of ALEDA BSS, including a Business Unit and a Human Resources Development Unit. The financial support covered 75% of the running cost, in addition to technical assistant to ALEDA team in improving management capacities. Moreover, in the framework of the collaboration with the technical support of UNDP and financial support of Lazio Region along with the Management Board of ALEDA BSS, Tow Mobile Market in the area of BSS has been implemented during 2016, as a venue and platform to support the valorization of local value chains, namely Handicrafts & Agro-food processing was launched in 2014. The objectives of the market are: • To revive and promote the traditional economic sectors of food processing and hand craft production targeting limited income generating women/men (limited financial capabilities) and new startups • To create new markets that will promote the local traditional-food processing and handicrafts production sectors • To improve the capacities of local entrepreneurs • To support the value chain for food processing and crafts within the seven municipalities • To promote society interaction among different producers and
- Ensure that the Decentralized Cooperation is strengthened - Ensure that the capacity of the Local Economic Development in the BSS is enhanced

comment.narrative: •High unemployment amongst youth and women; •Limited job opportunities and weak private sector investment; •Loss and/or depletion of livelihood assets, and economic opportunities •Weak economic and productive infrastructures; •Limited financial services targeting poor and vulnerable people. •Limited knowledge on the available services by the local communities is contributing to the increasing tension. •Lack of services •Vulnerable population unable to access services •Lack of participatory mechanisms for service delivery •Local communities are vulnerable to external shocks due to limited skills and institutionalized mechanisms for preventing tension from exploding into conflict. •Lack of institutionalized local level mechanisms for dealing with disputes. •Lack of systematic conflict prevention and conflict resolution instruments being utilized by local leaders. •Limited skill base of key local leaders in dealing with disputes and conflicts affecting their villages.
▪ At least 50 Inter-Sectorial Municipal Action Plans developed ▪ At least 60 host communities targeted ▪ At least 170 projects implemented across different sectors
- 125 communities mapped through MRR - 48 communities involved in the MSS - 173 projects completed in 2016 - 121 most vulnerable communities targeted and 6 union of municipalities.
▪ At least 50 Inter-Sectorial Municipal Action Plans developed ▪ At least 40 host communities targeted ▪ At least 170 projects implemented across different sectors

Progress and main achievements in 2017: • 34 income generation initiatives were supported across a range of interventions related to youth employability, SMEs/cooperatives support, and economic Infrastructure. • 115 youth were integrated in the labour market through youth employment initiatives. • 167 MSMEs/Cooperatives were supported through technical and in-kind support and 307 MSMEs/Cooperatives benefited from youth employability services. • 6 value chain assessments were initiated: 3 in agriculture (Freekeh, Oregano and Honey) and 3 in renewable energy. • 5 partners involved in business and employment support (Chambers of Commerce of Zahle, Business Incubators: BIAT, and NGOs: Makhzoumi, AL Majmoua’a and SHIELD) were engaged in the youth employability project. • One vocational training center in Hariri Foundation was supported through rehabilitation and provision of equipment. • Two joint initiatives were implemented with the private sector targeting 20 women cooperatives to improve their market outreach (Cascada Mall and Nature). • 14 multi-sectoral sub-national plans (cluster level MRRs) were developed and 206 multi-sectoral local plans (community level MRRs) were updated. • 635 participants (536 men and 99 women) were involved in the development of the cluster plans; 5496 participants (3941 Males 1555 Females) were involved in the communities’ plans. • 27 projects in Basic Services were completed benefiting 31 vulnerable communities in response to the Syrian crisis and 42 projects were implemented in the Palestinian Gatherings. • A rapid poverty assessment undertaken with the Ministry of Social Affairs was finalized.

• Support the MoIM, SCEC, Constitutional and State Councils in the planning, organization and conduct of the municipal elections in its different stages. • Support the process of candidates registration for municipal elections and parliamentary bi-elections through the implementation of a modern candidate registration software (pilot) conducted in parallel with the current system. • Support in the design and conduct of trainings for the candidate registration officials at 26 'Qaem maqams'. • Technical support to the 26 'Qaem maqams' during the candidate registration period • Support in the establishment of the MoIM media center and hotline, and support for the maintenance and development of the website • Regular trainings and briefings for media and observers on municipal elections (depending on pre-elections period length) • Support the MoIM and Civil Society Organizations in the organization and conduct of cascade trainings for polling officials, accreditation unit, media and observers, hotline operators, CSO representatives, and women organizations • Technical support to the MoIM Operation Room during the electoral period. • Organization and conduct of meetings between MoIM and persons with disabilities NGOs in order to identify concrete measures to increase accessibility to the polling locations. • Conducting at least 3 full awareness campaigns (media and direct targeting) aiming at voter education, voter registration, and elections day requirements. • Conducting a national workshop on strengthening the participation of women in municipal elections as voters, candidates and polling officials. • Development of a guide for municipal elections focused on candidacy procedure (Arabic and English) aimed to to provide relevant information to women interested to run as candidates. • Ensure proper evaluation of programs and highlighting of lessons learned after the completion of the municipal elections with a focus on women participation; Post-electoral evaluation
LEAP focused in 2016 to successfully support the implementation of the 2016 municipal elections and building all necessary capacities for parliamentary elections planned in 2017

In 2017, and following the approval of the country's first proportional electoral law, the project worked towards building the sustainable capacity for the management and administration of elections. It accordingly prepared an assessment of teh main operational needs, budget estimates, and timeline of the implementation of the 2018 parliamentary elections. The project prepared a technical and feasibility study on the updates required for the candidates' registration system, and results' management, and provided all the necessary equipment for implementation. It also developed a feasibility study and samples of the pre-printed ballots, which will be used for the first time in Lebanese elections. It also supported the Ministry in updating and upgrading the official elections portal and website, and assisted in preparing the voters' roll. Following the appointment of the 11 members of the Supervisory Commission for Elections, the project developed a full technical and operational support plan covering briefing toolkit, identification and preparation of premises (incl. civil works and furniture), provision of all necessary equipment for operations, and administrative assistance. During this reporting period, the project procured needed equipment for the Constitutional Council that would facilitate, enhance and speed up their work during the 2018 Parliamentary elections. In addition, during this period, LEAP produced and published the French version of the Constitutional Council’s Decisions from 1994 to 2016 in two volumes: volume 1 includes the decisions related to the constitutionality of the laws; and volume 2 entails the decisions related to electoral disputes. One thousand copies of each volume were delivered to the Council who will distribute them to relevant partners and institutions such as universities, public libraries, relevant NGOs, among others. Finally, LEAP has focused on support towards vulnerable groups including People with Disabilities, women, and you

description.narrative: Non formal dialogue and consensus building sessions held and maintained Reconciliation, and legislative processes facilitated and resourced. All-party Expert and Dialogue Groups established At least 300 dialogue sessions of the all-party Expert and Dialogue Groups conducted and supported by the Common Space (at least 300 dialogue sessions during the 5 years) Number of joint publications reflecting areas of consensus within the all-party Expert and Dialogue Groups Dialogue sessions and consultations are regularly held and maintained at least once a month Reconciliation, and legislative processes facilitated and resourced Practice to Theory learning workshops organized Case studies produced for comparative learning Peer-to-peer exchanges organized Annual conference organized

comment.narrative: Building on the achievements of the previous phase, there is a need to provide further technical support to national dialogues, policy making bodies, and consensus building mechanisms provided Need to strengthen capacities of stakeholders on sustainable peace, and to draw on legacy of consensus building and Lebanese culture of dialogue, and national assets There is a lack of initiatives that build long-term confidence, interdependence and trust at the national and community levels There is a need to provide and share facilitation support and deadlock breaking mechanisms; joint learning experiences, in Lebanon and the region

- Holding at least 75 dialogue sessions - Development of at least 5 knowledge tools - Developing new dialogue tools to address impacts of the Syrian crisis - Organize the "Practice to Theory Conference" to favor peer to peer exchange - Maintain and further develop knowledge-sharing platforms, to reach out to at least 20% of additional users - Commission at least 5 case studies and research papers on comparative learning and experiences, in Lebanon and the region
CSI operated at minimal capacity in view of changing environment; providing peer/south-south support to the Syria dialogue process; and focused on resource mobilization activities.

Support to the national dialogues’ structures, mechanisms and committees:
• Support to dialogues, dialogue structures, policy-making bodies, and consensus building mechanisms provided.
Support to problem solving and consensus building, on essential policy issues:
• Political and constitutional reforms and dialogues supported and strengthened. • Deadlock breaking mechanisms, safety nets, and civil peace support created. • Regional technical support and knowledge resources provided. • Common Space Initiative operations and management efficiency enhanced.

Several of the key dialogue, joint knowledge creation and change initiatives launched by CSI-UNDP over the past three years saw significant results in 2017. As is the nature of systemic approaches and knowledge-based dialogues addressing deep-root causes of conflicts and differences, it took time for parties to reach common understanding. On the Lebanese-Palestinian Dialogue front, the project finalized and agreed on the follow-up vision document with specific focus on implementation priorities. Published in October 2017, this expanded joint vision and roadmap deals with Lebanese-Palestinian political and diplomatic relations at national level: the relationship between the Lebanese State and the State of Palestine, including the PLO and the PA; and the Palestinian presence in Lebanon and its various aspects -- diplomatic representation, popular representation, Lebanese-Palestinian joint responsibility towards UNRWA, camps human security. Also, in 2017 the project continued its engagement with key advisers of the President of the Republic on the President’s initiative to create a permanent “dialogue institute” ; the implementation of Taef; and the future design of a reconstructed “National Dialogue that can lead to the establishment of the Senate. Other main initiatives pursued by the project in previous years were materialized in 2017, including the submission of a draft decentralization law to parliament, as well as the revival of the Economic and Social Campaign, for which recommendations were developed by the project in 2015.

-Implementation of at least 1.75 MW of decentralized renewable energy projects is initiated with the support of a technical firm; -A number of studies is completed in partnership with other projects and published (Renewable Energy Interconnection Grid Code; Derisking Renewable Energy Investment Study; Net-metering Study) -A number of capacity building workshops are conducted (Earthing and Lightning Protection of PV Systems, Embedding of PV technologies in building design and construction, Net-metering) and related guidelines are issued; -PV Survey is undertaken and Market Monitoring Reporting is established; -Quality Control of PV Installations is introduced in vocational schools through updating the curriculum and personnel training.

-Evaluation of 13 beneficiary application forms for the demonstration projects is completed and 9 beneficiaries/facilities were selected totalling a capacity of 2.6 MWp. -Site visits for the 9 selected facilities are completed and 6 design reviews are finalised with 3 more to go. -6 MOUs have been signed with the beneficiaries applying for the NEEREA loan before implementation can begin. -Grid Code Data Assessment and Guidelines Reports completed and transferred to MoEW for review and recommendation. -Lebanon's first PV Status Report has been launched for 2015: total installed capacity for Solar PV is 10 MWp worth $31M. -The mission to Beirut for the Derisking Renewable Energy Investment Study is completed and the first draft report is currently under review. -Earthing and Lightning Protection for PV Systems Workshop conducted with attendees from various private sector companies and EDL. The purpose of it was to present the proper guidelines to be used for grounding and protecting Solar PV systems from lightning and faults. -Additional PV quality standards have been approved and adopted in collaboration with LIBNOR/MoI. -Translation from English to French of the PV course which will be embedded in the vocational schools' Electrotechnical curriculum is completed. Work is underway to have it adopted in the curricu

Annual Output Results
Output Indicator

description.narrative: -Availability of end-use renewable energy units -Number of persons with increased access to energy

comment.narrative: Limited electricity supply and limited application of renewable energy technologies at host communities.

-100% of total location of street lighting poles has been identified and implementation is completed. - Solar lighting kits: 500 PV lighting kits were distributed in both Bekka and Akkar areas; - The technical evaluation of the "Survey and Assessment of the Implications on Electricity in Lebanon from the Current Syrian Crisis" was finalized, the related contract was awarded and signed; the kick-off meeting was held in June 2016; - 2 sites, Jabal Amel Hospital in the South of Lebanon, and the Orphan Welfare Society in Saida were selected for the installation of a 125 kWp and a 303 kWp solar photovoltaic system, respectively (providing a 25% grant for the supply and installation of these systems).

DFIF funds: -320 solar power street lighting to be installed in Dinniyeh area; -300 solar home systems to be installed in Dinniyeh area; -Installation of the 65 transformers in various sites.
NLD II Energy: - Procurement of minimum 36 low voltage transformers in key localities in the Bekaa and the South; - Identification of 18 solar PV for public-service institutions and/or solar PV pumping systems; - Design and procurement of 2 biomass briquetting process machines.
NLD II Solid Waste: - Identification of at least 2 open dumpsites for closure based on national updated masterplan and initiate turnkey support. - Identification of at least 3 municipalities to support in ISWM activities and design of masterplan and interventions. Undertake procurement of equipment. - Supporting some of the concerned municipalities on Solid Waste Management - Plan and implement at least 4 SWM coordination meetings for the sector - Prepare SWM guidance document in coordination with MOE

DFID funds: Supply of low to medium voltage transformers and poles completed in 79 sites, implementation of 270 solar-powered street lighting systems on public roads, solar home systems, and the supply of solar home systems to 978 households are completed.
Lebanon Recovery Funds (LRF): The implementation of solar street lighting in 10 to 15 villages is initiated: the contract has been signed, solar street pole location identification is on the way.
Funds from the Kingdom of the Netherlands phase II - Energy Component: - Beneficiary application form for the installation of RE systems for social services institutions was launched, evaluated and 16 sites were selected; implementation was initiated in 11 sites; bidding document for the implementation at the remaining 4 sites are being evaluated; - Supply and installation of 40 low to medium voltage transformers and poles is initiated.
Funds from the Kingdom of the Netherlands phase II - Solid Waste Component: - Bar Elias: The project prepared the ToRs for the implementation of the turnkey activities to construct one of the four cells planned under the ESFD project; however, the launching of the bid is still pending the operation of the sorting/composting facilities; - North Baalbek: The project undertook the technical and financial feasibility of implementing a sorting (60t/d) and/or landfill facility for a cluster of nine villages north of Baalbek. - Qaraoun and other villages within the Lake union: The project is supporting the municipalities of Qaraoun, Lala, Khirbet Qanafar, Saghbine, and Sohmor on solid waste management through training and awareness raising on Sorting at Source along with the provision of the necessary bins and equipment. - Training of Municipalities: The project is undertaking the development of an environmental training program for municipalities on environmental management. - Coordination: the project is providing technical supp

'NLD II Energy: - Monitoring the implementation and commissioning of 40 transformers; - Monitoring the implementation and commission the installation of 11 PV systems in selected sites; - The implementation of 2 biogas sites is assessed.
LRF Street lighting: - The installation of 320 PV street lighting is completed at selected sites (10 - 15 villages).
NDL II Solid Waste: - Completion of the "Sorting at Source" awareness raising campaign for the targeted villages within the lake union of municipalities (west Bekaa), construction of the recyclables sorting facility, and the provision of bins and equipment. - The municipalities are trained on environmental management; - The turnkey construction of the North Baalbek sorting or lanfilling facility is completed and commissioned; - The construction of the Bar Elias sanitary landfill cell (pending the CoM's decision to include Bar Elias on the list to profit from the EU funds for the operation of the SWM plant) is initiated.

description.narrative: - Restructuring plans developed - Coordination initiatives enhanced -Launch specific social and economic projects including support to entrepreneurs - E-government platform and tools developed - Regular ICT Ministerial Committee meetings held at least quarterly - Number of developed ICT policies and regulations - Internal and external communication strategies developed and tested - Number of publications drafted and disseminated - Number of infrastructural projects developed and implemented

- Coordinate among Key Ministries and institutions including Ministries of Finance, Economy and Trade, Social Affairs, and IDAL, to propose relevant public policy reform plans and develop a medium-term development strategy - Provide Technical Support to the Central Administration of Statistics for a reform program for the statistical system and an implementation plan - Support in developing social development policies and coordinate the implementation of the Regional Development Strategy - Coordinate with OMSAR for developing e-government electronic tools and services and implementing them in at least 4 pilot projects - Coordinate with key ministries to Re-launch the meetings of the ICT Ministerial Committee - Coordinate with key ministries to propose at least 4 ICT/e-Governance procedures and policies - Support to Updating the ICT Watch website - Provide guidelines and technical support to the OPCM and other government agencies on all infrastructure projects
All planned results for 2016 were achieved; supported the establishment of new functions for 2017 based on new cabinet agenda and priorities

The project, and since its inception, has been providing substantive policy and technical support to the Office of the President of the Council of Ministers (OPCM), and has contributed to enhancing inter-ministerial coordination on macroeconomic policy matters and to improving the planning and implementation of development programs. In line with its main raison-d’être, and as indicated by the various economic, social, infra-structure or service projects it is has handled in 2017, the Project continued to building and enhancing the National Capacities at the Presidency of the Council of Ministers in general, more specifically within the OPCM. More specifically the project has contributed to mitigating the impacts of the Syrian displaced crisis, by providing support to the activities of the Lebanese Host Communities' Projects, the Lebanese Crisis Response Plan, and the Lebanese Recovery Fund, towards the mitigation of the impacts of the Syrian crisis. The project most importantly, finalized the Capital Investment Program, its funding mechanisms, and implementation road map. The project scaled up the National Poverty Targeting Program and developed a social safety net program to provide access to social benefits (mostly educational). In addition, it tackled business development and innovation through legislative reform. The business environment laws drafted have been grouped into one bucket, endorsed by the PM, and officially sent to key ministries for comments in order to be presented by the PM to cabinet. The bucket includes the following: bankruptcy law, insolvency practitioner’s law, judicial mediation law, secured lending law and private equity fund law. In addition the project implemented "Summer of Innovation", which promoted extracurricular activities in the fields of innovation, science, technology, entrepreneurship, and creativity to increase youth awareness, interest and participation in such activities. It also designed a pilot project for setting up Tec

capital of a political entity

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

title.narrative: Activity web page
Annual Output Results
Output Indicator

description.narrative: •Number of options for the organizational structure of LPDC •Number of options for the revised mandate of LPDC presented to the PM • Number of comparative studies conducted to explore the structures and mandates of parallel regional institutions dealing with Palestine refugees •Number of consultation sessions with political leaders to promote the draft law • Framework for collaboration between Palestinian and Lebanese authorities is set and activated. • Number of recruited international and local consultants. • Media campaign successfully implemented; • Number of census steering committee meetings; •Number of surveyed refugee camps and gatherings; • Census result analysed and published. • Number of meetings held with MOIM and DPRA • Number of options for computerizing the DPRA functions • Number of options for restructuring the DPRA for more effectiveness •# of coordination meetings and workshops. •# of regional platforms attended. •PRS registry system created at the Ministry of Interior. • Amount of funds received for Nahr El-Bared Project. • # f completed Units in NBC. • # of dialogue sessions. • Level of participation and commitments in Dialogue. • # of recommendations signed by the Working Group representatives.

comment.narrative: • Broad mandate of the LPDC in the 2005 decree. • A very broad and an undetailed 2013 draft law for the formation of the higher commission for Palestine Refugees. • Lack of official information on Palestinian refugees from public institutions. • Inconstancy in Palestinian refugees numbers and profiles across agencies. • Lack of policy-led tools based o accurate knowledge and information. • Absence of informative and analyzed statistical Data within governmental bodies. • Outdated registry records and deteriorated services provided to Palestinian refugees • DPRA administration still not computerized • The role of the DPRA has been limited to issuing personal status records • Lack of inter-governmental coordination on issues of camps and Gatherings. • Inconstancy in LPDC’s inter-ministerial committee meetings and decisions. • Lack of a culture of rights for Palestinian refugees among public institutions and service providers. • Ambiguity in institutional policies and procedures within ministries. •Shortage in the Nahr el-Bared reconstruction funding of $ 153 M. • Arrival of 43,000 newly arrived Palestinian and Syrian refugees from Syria in Lebanon. • Lack of a responsible stakeholder / institution in Palestinian portfolio other than LPDC. • Weak presence of the Lebanese Government in international and regional platforms (such as UNRWA Advisory Commission) that treats the Palestinian refugees. • Absence of official dialogue platforms among Lebanese and Palestinians. • Absence of Lebanese political unified position on the governmental policies towards refugees.

In 2017, LPDC with technical support of UNDP completed the population and housing census of Palestinian Refugees in Lebanon, and its results are expected to be made public by the end of December 2017 through a conference organised at the Prime Minister's Office. It is worth noting that this exercise is the first of its kind being implemented in Lebanon since the arrival of refugees from Palestine in 1948. This exercise constitutes a good basis for the Government of Lebanon to address Palestinian refugees' issues from a scientific perspective leading to future policy development and improvement of the conditions of Palestinian Refugees in Lebanon.

• A master plan and a two-year implementation strategy for common transportation (railways, and buses) developed. • Updated institutional and technical structural capacities of the RPTA; • Provision of support to the RPTA to coordinate and manage ongoing and potential technical projects. • Identification of priority needs for external funding and creating linkages with resource organizations.

In the framework of the UNDP – EIB cooperation agreement, on Lebanon’s needs for a reliable public transport sector through the working session at EIB premises, an initiative for developing Quick Win Projects in Lebanon in public transportation sector was considered as part og of the Economic Resilience Initiative (ERI) to support the countries affected by neighborhood countries crisis. The city of Tripoli was selected for a Quick Win Project for the implementation of a bus network system. As such, the EIB and the Ministry of Public works and Transport expressed a mutual interested to move forward and develop a new transport bus network, Integrated Tariff, Ticketing system and reform of public transport sector in the city. A grant of 1 Million Euros for the preparation of tender documentation and a detailed design for construction of Tripoli Bus Network and its terminals will be allocated by the Bank and the procurement procedure will take place beginning 2018.This component will assist RPTA in transforming and empowering the existing transport units into new entities able to undertake planning, regulation and coordination of all transport systems in Tripoli. As part of the objective of providing institutional support to the RPTA, an official assessment report of the current institutional regulations and frameworks was submitted by the legal consultant. A first achievement was reached in terms of revision of the legal and regulatory framework that governs the RPTA’s operations. The project also assisted RPTA on its vision to develop a mass transit system along the railway right-of-way starting from NBT area. In addition, UNDP unit in cooperation with OMSAR’s web development unit deployed a complaint management system application for RPTA and a first version of its webpage. The complaint management system implemented a positive impact on RPTA’s legal department and registry affairs office by offering an e-filing system for a reliable. Finally, the unit promoted RPT

comment.narrative: Social development strategy, MDG-based national development programme, and poverty reduction strategy elaborated and safety nets, including targeting HIV/AIDS patients, expanded
Establishment of project and project steering committee Selection and mobilization of member Awareness among board members on SDGs Selection of 2017 SDG focus
All results achieved as planned

Mainstream projects related to quality education Create and disseminate knowledge on private sector development Link the project with other opportunities for private sector development Gear CSR of private sector towards quality education

In 2017, the project successfully mainstreamed activities in the framework of the selected SDG: "Quality Education" (SDG4). At the national level, it provided support to the Tripoli Special Economic Zone by providing a Skills Gap Analysis, looking into available resources, educational programs, and suggesting recommendation to the Zone and other relevant stakeholders on the implementation of the recommendations. The project also developed a Concept Note presented to the Ministry of Education and Higher Education on Cooperative Education. The proposal should be matched with required resources and partnerships in 2018. The project also cooperated with the Municipality of Tyre and Rotaract on education on road safety, placing billboards throughout the city on emergency numbers and road safety tips. Finally, the project focused on education through women empowerment, training more than 100 women from 5 regions on entrepreneurial skills, and had a more focused approach with 25 women on the development of business plans and concrete projects, also supporting them in mobilizing resources. More than 10 projects were materialized so far.

description.narrative:
For output 1: Indicator 1: National Disaster Management Authority established with dedicated staff, office space, equipment and budget allocations
Indicator 2: The PCM set up a system of planning, monitoring and evaluation to ensure that DRR is integrated into its policies, procedures and plans for increasing resilience of national development schemes/projects
Indicator 3: Technical capacity of government officials and other stakeholders enhanced to address disaster risk reduction in development planning
Indicator 4: National Response Plan implemented and stakeholders have enhanced tools and capabilities
Indicator 5: Mobile Operation Room/Vehicle fully equipped and functional
Indicator 6: Critical sectors and remaining Mouhafaza have improved their response capacities in line with the National response mechanism and are linked to the national operation room
For output 2: Indicator 1: Localized risk maps produced by the CNRS for Refugee Hosting high-risk local authorities
Indicator 2: Capacities of the CNRS improved for hazard forecasting and warning
Indicator 3: Early warning reports disseminated to stakeholders by the CNRS through a national multi-stakeholder early warning committee and using all other mediums of communication
Output 3: Indicator 1: Refugee-hosting local authorities implement DRR schemes/plans to reduce local vulnerability and build DRR capacity
Indicator 2: Local authorities are supported to integrated results of risk assessments into development planning including land-use instruments, in the building codes and environmental management practices
Indicator 3: Risk aware communities in refugee-hosting areas take proactive action to reduce disaster risks through DRR communication, grants and actual implementation of DRR activities; e.g. family preparedness, disaster resilient house construction etc;
Indicator 4: National Media awareness campaign targeting mass population centred around prevention and preparedness to disasters dissem

comment.narrative:
For Output 1:
Baseline 1: National disaster risk management policy and national platform institution non-existing
Baseline 2: Disaster risk reduction continues to stay a low priority in national development planning
Baseline 3: Critical national infrastructure and assets have high exposure to natural hazards;
Baseline 4: NOR still lacks necessary software for advanced flow of operations
Baseline 5: CBRN not integrated within the National Response Framework
Baseline6: MOR still needs equipment to be finalized
Baseline7: Ministry of Public Works does not have a response plan or an operation room linked to the NOR
For output 2: Baseline 1: National risk information systems including risk analysis and early warning are weak
Baseline 2: National development agencies (ministries, municipalities) lack useable information about impending hazards; e.g. localized hazard maps, early warning, in order to implement DRR actions;
Baseline 3: Mass population in general and population at risk especially hosting communities and refugees lack DRR awareness
For output 3: Baseline 1: Exposure & vulnerability of refugee-hosting local authorities increased due to overwhelming number of Syrian refugees
Baseline 2: Awareness & preparedness of communities is low with regards to disaster prevention and mitigation
Baseline 3: Disaster risk reduction not integrated into local authorities planning and capacities for DRR remain low
For output 4: Baseline: Lebanon institutions have experience in recovery management

1.2 Support in set up of a fully functional and operational central National Operations Room (NOR) 1.2.1 At least 1 table top exercise/Simulation held at the PCMs to provide hands-on exposure to its leadership and staff concerning integration of DRR into specific upcoming projects. Each year, the exercises will focus on one hazard or risk . 1.2.2 ESRI Software Training (2016)
1.3 Mainstreaming CBRN into national DRR plans 1.3.1 CBRN Sector Consultant for the integration of CBRN within pilot sector 1.3.2 Organize small simulation/table top to test the integration of CBRN into the one sector in line with the National Response Framework
1.4 Support Critical sectors Mouhafaza in preparing and responding to Disasters 2016 1.4.1 Upgrading and rehabilitation of Governorate of Mount Lebanon Operation Room
3.1 Upgrade and Complete response tools and equipment for an average of 3 regional operation rooms (Akkar, Baalbek, South) with active boards (AKKAR, Baalbek, Mount Lebanon, Bekaa), GIS Software (Akkar, Baalbek, South) including basic training on application
3.2 Empower one Union of Municipalities in each of the Governorate of Akkar and Governorate of Baalbek in 2017 and in 2018 to mitigate the impacts of the Syrian crisis through the development of: 3.2.1 Development of Response Plan workshop 4,000 USD for each union 3.2.2 Development of related capacity building 3.2.3 Provision of equipment and Tools 11,000USD for each union (Furniture and Laptops) 3.2.4 Implementation of Pilot mitigation projects within one Union of municipalities including but not restricted to awareness raising, provision of needed tools, and implementation of pilot projects for infrastructure etc. (this activity will be conducted through a grant agreement with a local NGO 120,000USD per union)
3.3 DRR Communication: 3.3.1 Development and dissemination of DRR awareness material at the local level (15 out of 30) 3.3.2 Procurement of serevices for a communication consultant technical su

1 table top exercise was organised at the Prime Minister's Office to provide hands-on exposure to its leadership and staff concerning integration of DRR into specific upcoming projects; ESRI Software Training was completed for intergrating GIS mapping into DRM response; CBRN integrated into the national response framework and into 1 pilot sector and 1 table top exercise conducted to test the integration of CBRN; Governorate of Mount Lebanon Operation Room completed; Provision of equipment and Tools for union of Hermel (Furniture and Laptops) Partially accomplished; IDRR Day organised at the Grand Serail for the first time in the presence of the Minister of interior representing the Prime Minister;

description.narrative: % of Paris III commitments implementation

comment.narrative: Limited implementation of Paris III reforms

- Implement at least 6 missions, among which at least 3 with new beneficiary institutions - Develop at least 3 new forms of partnership with stakeholders - Increase TOKTEN's expatriate database of at least 10% (with a special focus on women) - Develop and implement a new Communication strategy
All intended targets achieved as planned

• Providing access to the latest Internationals standard of care in cancer treatment for the most vulnerable part of the population through National Cancer Treatment Guidelines 3rd edition: • Supporting in the control of abuse insure better health result in the proper application of the National Orthopedic and Spine Implants published in 2016 by TOKTEN through training of MOH inspectors • Improvement of the correctional system • Building capacity on the latest Financial investigation techniques and procedures • Enabling enforcement agencies to improve crime fighting and prevention through cybersecurity training

In 2017, the TOKTEN project has successfully implemented 6 missions and worked towards the development of new partnerships. The project conducted a support mission to the Ministry of Environment to develop an air quality strategy and a related 3 years work plan. In addition a mission was conducted to assess the prisons' management with the support of the Canadian correctional facilities, and a report submitted to the Ministry of Interior and Municipalities, along with recommendations. A mission to the Lebanese Armed Forces' Intelligence built capacities on cybersecurity of Intelligence IT officers on the latest tools. Another mission tackled data mining for urban areas, the National Center for Remote Sensing (NCRS) was supported in building a system that is deployable to nation-wide urban sprawl detection. With the Ministry of Health, TOKTEN worked on the publication and launching of the 3rd National Cancer Treatment Guidelines and organized the $100 Million spent on Cancer Treatment based on international standards of Care protocol guidelines. By end of year a mission was conducted with the Ministry of Industry to train technicians and engineers on food safety protocols. Finally, the project signed a new agreement with G. Vincenti on a partnership around Zero Hunger and Food Safety to be implemented in 2018.

description.narrative: 1.1 Clearance information continues to be updated daily on IMSMA to support sound prioritization and decision making. 1.2 Data entry activities into IMSMA and data quality checks are completely and independently handled by the LMAC after 34 months of project commencement 1.3 Community liaison and rapid response activities are completely and independently handled by the LMAC after 28 months of project commencement 1.4 The Communications Room is operated by the LMAC after 22 months of project commencement 1.5 A consolidated socio-economic report is generated annually 1.6 Accreditation and QA/ QC is phased over to the LMAC after 38 months of project commencement 2.1 At least 3 MRE committee meetings and 2 meetings with the relevant ministries are facilitated and held annually 2.2 At least one MRE awareness raising campaign is implemented each year, with the active participation of the MRE Steering Committee 2.3 Support is provided to ensure that MRE sessions target areas that are identified to have a higher risk rate 3.1 At least 3 MVA committee meetings and 2 meetings with the relevant ministries are facilitated and held annually 3.2 At least one MVA campaign is implemented each year, with the active participation of the MVA Steering Committee and victims 3.3 Support is provided to draft proposals to secure funding that would enable completion of a national survey of victims and their needs 3.4 Support is provided to keep victims’ data up-to-date on IMSMA 3.5 At least 2 meetings are held with well-established private sector organization to discuss potential collaboration annually 4.1 The development of the relevant SOPs in compliance with NMAS 2015 has been facilitated through two workshop 4.2 A mid-term review report for milestone 2016 has been issued as well as an exit strategy 4.3 At least 1 networking meetings are held annually to activate the inter-ministerial advisory committee 4.4 An ISG meeting is held annually to encourage fund mobilization

comment.narrative:
Baselines for Result 1: -Clearance information is updated continuously and its quality checked by the GIS clerks on IMSMA and GIS to support sound prioritization and decision making -The project staff is providing support to rapid response and to the operation of the communications room through 3 CLOs and 1 radio operator. All calls and reports are handled within less than 24 hours. -Demining organizations are preparing socio-economic impact reports, but no consolidated socio-economic report exists -Accreditations for demining organizations are being issued with one-year validity. The project staff is monitoring the accreditation and updating the status of this accreditation.
Baselines for Result 2: -Ad hoc MRE steering committee meetings are being organized with limited ministerial participation -One or two ad hoc meetings are taking place with MRE concerned ministries annually -One MRE awareness campaign is being supported annually in cooperation with the MRE Steering Committee. -MRE data is being collected and input into IMSMA with limited analysis
Baselines for Result 3: -Ad hoc MVA steering committee meetings are being organized with limited ministerial participation -One or two ad hoc meetings are taking place with MVA concerned ministries annually -No national MVA campaign is currently being implemented. -Victim data remains incomplete -Liaising with the private sector is limited
Baselines for Result 4: -The NMAS has been updated but the SOPs do not yet reflect the updates. -A mid-term review report for milestone 2013 has been issued. -No exit strategy has yet been developed -The inter-ministerial advisory committee is still not active -Although the number of capacity building workshops is being planned, the needs are not being comprehensively and systematically assessed -Participation in regional and international platforms is supported in terms of financing and logistics, as well as in terms of speeches, presentations, and networking

1.1 Clearance information continues to be updated daily on IMSMA to support sound prioritization and decision making. 1.5 A consolidated socio-economic report is generated annually 2.1 At least 3 MRE committee meetings and 2 meetings with the relevant ministries are facilitated and held annually 2.2 At least one MRE awareness raising campaign is implemented each year, with the active participation of the MRE Steering Committee 2.3 Support is provided to ensure that MRE sessions target areas that are identified to have a higher risk rate 3.1 At least 3 MVA committee meetings and 2 meetings with the relevant ministries are facilitated and held annually 3.2 At least one MVA campaign is implemented each year, with the active participation of the MVA Steering Committee and victims 3.3 Support is provided to draft proposals to secure funding that would enable completion of a national survey of victims and their needs 3.4 Support is provided to keep victims’ data up-to-date on IMSMA 3.5 At least 2 meetings are held with well-established private sector organization to discuss potential collaboration annually 4.2 A mid-term review report for milestone 2016 has been issued 4.3 At least 1 networking meetings are held annually to activate the inter-ministerial advisory committee 4.4 An ISG meeting is held annually to encourage fund mobilization 4.5 A needs assessment is conducted annually and a short report produced 4.6 Participation in at least 2 regional and 3 international platforms is supported in terms of financing, logistics, and representation (speeches, presentations, side events…) 4.7 Support is provided for the inauguration of the RSHDL and the transfer of the AOP management to Lebanon. 4.8 Lebanon has met the due dates to report on its international obligations and transparency measures

description.narrative: No. of policy reforms legislated and implementation plans adopted

comment.narrative: Administrative Reform Strategy adopted by Office of the State for Administrative Reform in 2012, small and medium enterprise strategy developed in 2014, Statistical Master plan developed (2015)

1. Governance, accountability and transparency enhanced in the public sector. 2. Capacity of Public administration developed through the adoption of modern techniques and tools. 3. Human resources management modernised and developed 4. Public services efficiency enhanced and the administration/citizens relationship improved 5. The use of ICT tools enhanced and an E-Government portal established 6. Technical and Administrative support provided to ensure the proper execution of awarded contract with the scope of the following specialized projects: Solid Waste, AFKAR and LOGO. 7. Change management techniques introduced and OMSAR reform programs promoted

In 2017, the project reached results under the 6 main outcomes defined in the new Project Document. The project played an active role in the enactment of the Access to Information Law, which led to the improvement in the rating of Lebanon by two points which make it eligible for the Open Government Partnership. Moreover, the project developed the job description for the function “Information Officer” specified in the access to information law and conducted the required follow-up on the related nominations. Additionally, a high level National Strategy for anticorruption was developed through a committee hosted and supported by the project. Also in 2017, 900 government staff took advanced training on public procurement best practices of whom, 20 staff took TOT courses. Moreover during 2017, the Public Procurement code of ethics was issued and the Public Procurement Integrity was finalized. Through the Sectoral and Organizational Performance Measurement and Inspection Programme, 603 Outcome Key Performance Indicators for the 6 sectoral pilot Ministries were developed in 2017 of which 439 composite outcome indicators and 3013 Sub-Key Performance outcome Indicators. Three Ministries out of the six will be able to report on their Outcome Indicators for 2017 from a Sectoral perspective (Ministry of Economy and Trade, Directorate General of Urban Planning and Directorate General of Hydraulic and Electric Resources) thus paving the way for the performance evaluation to be done by the Central Inspection beginning 2018. Moreover, through this methodology, a new performance area was introduced to link the indicators to the SDGs indicators and to put the basis for sectoral SDGs reporting. Under the Human Resources management and modernization component 1300 public personnel became active learners in the e-learning program “Boost Yourself” and 40 employees from the Civil Service Board have been trained in “Professional Management”.
