Establishing project basis Resource mobilization (human and financial) Partnership with UNFPA and other stakeholders established and consolidated Participating in the inception regional meeting
All targets met and project ready to be operational in 2017

• Capacity of law enforcement sector enhanced to respond to the needs of SGBV survivors in a safe and ethical way through: o A specific curriculum for Lebanese Judges institutionalized at the Institute of Judicial Studies o A specific curriculum for the Municipal Police developed and piloted with Municipalities • Generation of evidence and knowledge products supported in order to better target specific SGBV prevention and response intervention through: o Youth Protection needs of Educational Facilities located in displacement affected areas assessed o Awareness tools developed and piloted on involving boys and male youth on prevention of SGBV • Awareness raised and sustainable advocacy efforts supported aiming at improving SGBV perceptions through: o Media professionals sensitized on the need to provide safe and ethical coverage of SGBV

All interventions under the SGBV project contribute to the following global objective: “Capacity and technical expertise of institutional, operational, national and other key actors is strengthened to prevent and address CRSV”.
In 2017, the implementation focused on two main outputs:
1. Capacity of law enforcement sector enhanced to respond to the needs of SGBV survivors in a safe and ethical way: through the institutionalization of a SGBV curriculum for the Municipal Police at the ISF Academy. (preparatory measures) • Initiative formally approved by the ISF Academy. • Local Implementing Partner (i.e. KAFA (Enough Violence and Exploitation)) selected and contracted. • ToRs of the training needs assessment with the Municipal Police and the Heads of Municipality endorsed and approved by all parties, including MoIM.
2. Generation of evidence and knowledge products supported in order to better target specific SGBV prevention and response interventions: through the development of awareness tools on involving boys and male youth on prevention of SGBV.
• Desk review of guidance, tools and practices related to the engagement of men and boys (with a special attention on male youth) against violence against women and girls finalized . • Analytic report and Annexes (including FGD Guide, KI Guide, summary of findings and recommendations) finalized, endorsed and disseminated. • First draft national 3W mapping of actors and interventions (who-what-where) produced and submitted for review. • Outline of a contextualized Training Package on “Engaging with Males on VAWG” (outreach techniques and content) developed and submitted for review

comment.narrative: Progress status by 2016; Reports in the framework of the LCRP; already negotiated and signed trade agreements; established Enterprise unit; SMEs strategy (2014)

• Strengthened institutional capacities of the Ministry of Economy and Trade with respect to economic and trade policy formulation, public sector regulation and management streamlining, SME support and development, develop partnerships with the international organizations and institutions, and other related matters falling within the competences of the Ministry. • Increased Lebanese exports by improving the competitiveness of Lebanese products and meeting up the international quality and standards requirements. • MOET high impact delivery capacity for efficient private public sector cooperation institutionalized and transfer of skills to the administration enhanced.

In 2017, significant results were achieved on the legislation front by the project. Most of the laws drafted with the inputs of the project and passed in 2017, are expected to bring a solid positive impact to the economy and the country as a whole (e.g., PPP law which were issued in September 2017, law on SME definition, Consumer Protection law and others).
The Project’s work on trade issues also brings the promise of positive impact on at least 14% of the Lebanese economy as trade constitutes that proportion of activity in the services sector. The importance of trade also stems from several untapped sectors with solid potential and which continue to suffer from endemic challenges in access to markets specially the EU, studies and assessments had been conducted to guide the government of Lebanon in its trade safeguard measures and decisions. The most notable is the work on updating Lebanon’s WTO accession file, goods and services offer as well as the legislative Agenda. The project contributed to the regular update of trade indicators, and to the minister’s interactions with the diplomatic corps for negotiations on agreements, technical assistance and cooperation activities.
Additionally, the work on SMEs can be considered as targeting at least 95% of companies in the country, and close to 50% of the work force. The Project’s efforts in that regard have included providing guidelines for initiatives by ecosystem partners to tackle identified challenges. As such, the Project continues to work with the World Bank, the European Union, UN agencies, NGOs, private sector firms, and others by engaging with them in activities ranging from the SME Forum 2017 (towards the organization of which, the project played an instrumental role), to roundtables to identify challenges and develop solutions, all the way to conference participations to provide feedback, and leadership in the livelihoods sector of LCRP. The main focus of the project during the 2017 reporting period was on automation and on consolidation of ICT towards quality education. As such, the School Information Management System was deployed on all public schools PCs, with continuous technical and administrative support to 1260 public schools and 1600 private. This resulted in a 100% automation of grades' lists, and resolution of issues (more than 6,000 cases). It also lead to a successful management of official exams (both rounds) and for the publication and management of results. In addition the connectivity with 1266 public schools from 8 regions was completed to the Lebanese National Educational Network. Additionally, the project launched Office 365 Project for each student, teacher and staff in the Lebanese public schools. The aim of this project is to provide each student and each teacher within the public sector with an email and educational tool.It will reach all public schools, 40,000 teachers and 200,000 students. A Program has been developed to integrate the information of students and teachers within the SIMS database with Office 365 by using this data to create automatically the accounts for the students and teachers in the public sector before distributing these accounts to the correspondent user by the end of 2017. For the internal Ministry's administration, the project established an IT asset management system. The project also supported in the deployment of the Qitabi program.The impact of this program affects 500 primary schools, which have never used ICT equipment into education before and has reached more than 50000 students. The equipment distribution and training for the teachers to use these equipment has been accomplished for the 500 primary public schools that started integrating ICT into education by the beginning of this scholar year. It also built a state of art MEHE IT Datacenter and Disaster Recovery Data Center that can serve all public schools starting with the schools inf

description.narrative: . Institutional mechanisms and policies strengthened for improving the legal status of women and girls, eliminating gender based violence and promoting gender equality

comment.narrative: No previous Ministry of Women Affairs National women affairs strategy by NCLW No national executive capacity for women affairs
• A consolidated all-inclusive action plan for the OMSWA to mainstream gender equality at the national level developed. • Support to the OMSWA to coordinate and implement quick-win projects provided.

After the establishment of the project in February 2017, support was provided to the Ministry through different angles, including awareness raising, legal reform, strategy development, enhancement of women political participation, and capacity building. In terms of raising awareness, the project developed different communication tools, including a website, accounts on all social media outlets, and published a monthly newsletter, entitled "Women Voices". The project also had a number of media campaigns to advocate for a draft law on sexual harassment, gender equality, and women empowerment at all levels. A number of legal proposals were submitted to the Council of Ministers and Parliament, including penalization of sexual harassment, discrimination in terms of the National Social Security Fund, paternity leave, code of ethics for the media, municipal elections, etc... Some of the laws passed incl. abolition of Art. 522 of the Penal Code and amendments to the municipal elections law. In addition the project partnered with a number of counterparts on specific strategies to tackle key strategies from a gender perspective, including the Prevention of Violent Extremism Strategy, and a Strategy to combat Violence against Women. Most importantly, the project supported the Ministry in all consultations and drafting of the National Gender Equality Strategy (2017-2030) taking as a basis the SDGs. Women political participation was one of the main thematic areas on which the project focused in 2017. As such, it developed a partnership with LEAP and UN Women to come up with a national plan to enhance women participation and find alternatives to the absence of a quota. It also partnered with the Embassy and Government of Chile to hold regional workshops on women and politics. In this framework it also worked closely with the Presidency of the Council of Ministers on the appointment of women in leadership positions by making recommendations.
